Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status
Story:
I stared at my phone, my mother’s message still glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, tonight is the family prayer. It’s important to us.” Her words echoed the recent talks at home about keeping our traditions alive, especially now that my grandparents were getting older. I wanted to be there, to show I cared about our customs, to be the daughter my family expected.

But just as I was about to reply, my work app pinged. A customer was asking, “Where’s my order? I’ve been waiting for an hour!” I knew I had to respond quickly and professionally, keeping my tone calm and polite, even though I was already running behind on my deliveries. My boss had reminded us last week: “Customer service is everything. Be courteous, no matter what.”

I felt the pressure building inside me, torn between the warmth of my family’s expectations and the cold professionalism my job demanded. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, my heart pounding as I tried to figure out how to be both the dutiful daughter and the reliable delivery person at the same time.
